messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
text:
Purpose: 

Permaculture design course for beginners in function for the local farmers, or people who want to learn. And to teach people making their own design. 

Day1

What is permaculture?
Why we need permaculture? 
How do we apply it?

Learn about the design principles 
Learn about the zones
Learn about the different layers of a foodforest
How to start your design: design process

Day3

Practical exercises that apply this theory 

- Mulching 
- Swales 
- Raised beds
- Partner plants / Sacrificial plants
- Planting threes in arid and wet soil 
- Sun capture
- Wind protection
- How to deal with clay and sand soil. 
- How to build biomass 
- How to build compost/ different composting methods
- Storing energy and water
- Communicating barrels 
- Rocket stove
- Hot shower 
- Compost toilet

Day4
Making a design for your land or project

messages.from: Paulinho
messages.text:
1. Contracts with teachers: As we are 10 people working at Unidos, we have suggested that we start with wages of 30$ per person that will be 300$, for everyone working full time 5 hours per day. Expectationsveryone will be submitting his/her report at the end of the month with these reports we will be able to make our impact measurement of all our work and programs. this salary will be increased if we get more stakeholders to aim to support us financially. 
2. Terms and conditions with stakeholders: we have made so far rules and regulations, for terms and policies that with stakeholders we don't have more experience thus we will need your support on this. 
3. MOU with partnering organizations will keep you in the loop as well we will need your support.
4. Official Fundraisers: we have also had some friends that can contribute to our cause although there is no guarantee we will need to make a tool that can be presented talking about all the activities that we are running for example website or fundraising campaign of all the programs based on quality Education, Regenerative agriculture and technology .5.Fee from students: we will start gathering some fees from students of the next cohorts that can buy markers, papers, or other small expenses.
6. Keep OPM in the loop with milestones and decisions: we will visit the NSAMIZI officer in charge of livelihood and other potential local stakeholders working in agriculture and discuss how we can work in collaboration although we don't expect something big from them, we will share our monthly report to OPM and inform them all the steps that we will be passing through.

text_entities.text:
1. Contracts with teachers: As we are 10 people working at Unidos, we have suggested that we start with wages of 30$ per person that will be 300$, for everyone working full time 5 hours per day. Expectationsveryone will be submitting his/her report at the end of the month with these reports we will be able to make our impact measurement of all our work and programs. this salary will be increased if we get more stakeholders to aim to support us financially. 
2. Terms and conditions with stakeholders: we have made so far rules and regulations, for terms and policies that with stakeholders we don't have more experience thus we will need your support on this. 
3. MOU with partnering organizations will keep you in the loop as well we will need your support.
4. Official Fundraisers: we have also had some friends that can contribute to our cause although there is no guarantee we will need to make a tool that can be presented talking about all the activities that we are running for example website or fundraising campaign of all the programs based on quality Education, Regenerative agriculture and technology .5.Fee from students: we will start gathering some fees from students of the next cohorts that can buy markers, papers, or other small expenses.
6. Keep OPM in the loop with milestones and decisions: we will visit the NSAMIZI officer in charge of livelihood and other potential local stakeholders working in agriculture and discuss how we can work in collaboration although we don't expect something big from them, we will share our monthly report to OPM and inform them all the steps that we will be passing through.

text_entities.text:
#19 

What is meant by ‚Äúconnection‚Äù or ‚Äúconnectivity‚Äù?

Connection‚Äù or ‚Äúconnectivity‚Äù is referring to Internet access using a WiFi or GSM enabled device. Unlike Facebook‚Äôs version of getting access to only Facebook services, this is opening a new world of opportunity for those that currently struggle to have power, internet and digital identity.

example: 

The contractor (the teacher) signs in agreement with Unidos foundation they are part of a cooperative of entrepreneurs (the teachers), where self leadership and holicratic organisation supports the scaling and quality of service provided to clients (the students)

With taking in account the following:

1) you are accountable for the impact you bring
2) you are self driven 
3) you will help support the purpose of unidos
4) you teach the materials agreed upon by unidos
5) ...

6) unidos is not accountable for any damage material or personal (meaning in the worst circumstances if something escalates, the teacher is fully accountable)

text:
Who is eligible to pay?
CATEGORIES OF PERSONS ELIGIBLE TO PAY LST
Categories of persons eligible to pay Local
Service Tax include the following:
(a)Person in gainful employment (with salaries
and wages)

(medical
and veterinary doctors, engineers, accountants,
consultants, technicians, lawyers, dentists, pharmacists,
architects, scientists, surveyors, valuers, ICT specialists
and any other self-employed professionals not
mentioned).
(c) Self-employed artisans(craftsmen, plumbers, builders,
electricians, masons, carpenters, mechanics, blacksmiths,
painters, welders, bakers, furniture makers, florists, skilled
artisans and any other artisans not mentioned excluding
sole petty artisans and ‚Äújuakalis‚Äù, who are not fully
established and not business entities).
(e) Commercial farmers
Who is exempted from paying Local Service Tax?
ÔÅ∂ Salaries of the following are exempted from the
payment of local service tax:
(a) Members of the Uganda People‚Äôs Defense
Force.
(b) Members of the Uganda Police Force.
(c) Members of the Uganda Prisons Service.
(d) Members of the Local Defense forces
sometimes referred to as LDU‚Äôs; and
(e) Members of the Diplomatic missions
accredited to Uganda.
ÔÅ∂ The following persons are also exempt from the
payment of local service tax.
(a) Unemployed persons and peasants.
(b) A person engaged in subsistence or
occasional economic activities.
(c) Petty food vendors.
(d) Boarder-Boarder (BODA-BODA) cyclists.
(e) Sole petty artisans and juakalis, who are not
fully established and are not business entities;
and
(f) People living in poverty who are unable to
earn a minimum income to access basic
necessities of life.

text_entities.text:
Who is eligible to pay?
CATEGORIES OF PERSONS ELIGIBLE TO PAY LST
Categories of persons eligible to pay Local
Service Tax include the following:
(a)Person in gainful employment (with salaries
and wages)
(b) Self-employed and practicing professionals

(medical
and veterinary doctors, engineers, accountants,
consultants, technicians, lawyers, dentists, pharmacists,
architects, scientists, surveyors, valuers, ICT specialists
and any other self-employed professionals not
mentioned).
(c) Self-employed artisans(craftsmen, plumbers, builders,
electricians, masons, carpenters, mechanics, blacksmiths,
painters, welders, bakers, furniture makers, florists, skilled
artisans and any other artisans not mentioned excluding
sole petty artisans and ‚Äújuakalis‚Äù, who are not fully
established and not business entities).
(e) Commercial farmers
Who is exempted from paying Local Service Tax?
ÔÅ∂ Salaries of the following are exempted from the
payment of local service tax:
(a) Members of the Uganda People‚Äôs Defense
Force.
(b) Members of the Uganda Police Force.
(c) Members of the Uganda Prisons Service.
(d) Members of the Local Defense forces
sometimes referred to as LDU‚Äôs; and
(e) Members of the Diplomatic missions
accredited to Uganda.
ÔÅ∂ The following persons are also exempt from the
payment of local service tax.
(a) Unemployed persons and peasants.
(b) A person engaged in subsistence or
occasional economic activities.
(c) Petty food vendors.
(d) Boarder-Boarder (BODA-BODA) cyclists.
(e) Sole petty artisans and juakalis, who are not
fully established and are not business entities;
and
(f) People living in poverty who are unable to
earn a minimum income to access basic
necessities of life.

messages.text:
Since we cannot supply enough compost for all farmers, we will be teaching them how to make vermicompost, using local resources, and how to maintain it. And we will explore the cost-benefit analysis with those who want to commercialize and sell their compost. For people who cannot make their own compost, convince them to keep all food waste for us.

As more people begin to produce more compost,and apply it to their respective farms, we will be healing and regenerating the soil, which in return will enable higher yield productivity.

messages.text:
Dear Paulino

This is a strong application and vermicomposting is an interesting focus. Unfortunately, we felt that the Ugandan food growing context is challenging for us to get transferable data as the land available to farmers far exceeds that in camps and settlements outside of Uganda
Sadly we are unable to fund you in this instance but will be offering a webinar¬†on 29th July for all Re-Alliance members on what funders expect from funding applications and hope this will be useful to you. We will send you more details nearer the time.

Best regards

Juliet

I will send a response


Hi dear attendee,

I respond to further comprehend your decision. 

For what I understand you compare Ugandan farmland with Other African nations, correct? 

Do you mean, there is more need in other countries?

We are however Congolese refugees from the refugee settlement Nakivale, and access to land is limited for us. So we dont  have the same benefits as casual Ugandan citizens.

To be clear, in the refugee settlement people are challenged with malnutrition due to increasing food prices, and poor access to fertile land for farming. These circumstance has all sort of other negative side effect, such as: teenage prostitution, crime, disease, unschooled children.

Let me add a complete profile in attachements for better understanding. 

Thanks for taking your time.

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
messages.text:
Hi,

I respond to further comprehend your decision. 

You say you lack transferable data, what do you mean by that?

And for what I understand you compare Ugandan farmland with Other African nations.

Do you mean, there is more need in other countries?

We are however Congolese refugees from the refugee settlement Nakivale, and access to land is limited for us. So we dont have the same benefits as casual Ugandan citizens.

To be clear, in the refugee settlement people are challenged with malnutrition due to rapidly increasing population, tripling food prices, and poor access to fertile land for farming. These circumstance has all sort of other negative side effect, such as: teenage prostitution, crime, disease, unschooled children.

Can you recommend an organisation that could support a project of our context?

text_entities.text:
Hi,

I respond to further comprehend your decision. 

You say you lack transferable data, what do you mean by that?

And for what I understand you compare Ugandan farmland with Other African nations.

Do you mean, there is more need in other countries?

We are however Congolese refugees from the refugee settlement Nakivale, and access to land is limited for us. So we dont have the same benefits as casual Ugandan citizens.

To be clear, in the refugee settlement people are challenged with malnutrition due to rapidly increasing population, tripling food prices, and poor access to fertile land for farming. These circumstance has all sort of other negative side effect, such as: teenage prostitution, crime, disease, unschooled children.

Can you recommend an organisation that could support a project of our context?

messages.from: Paulinho
messages.text:
Dear Paulinho,


It's a pleasure to be in touch with you. How are you? Thank you so much for your application in Re-Alliance's recent tendering process.


One of my colleagues may have been in touch to thank you for your application already. After review, we would like to move your application to the next stage of the process.


The next stage of the¬†process involves a call with me to discuss further. We have up to GBP¬£4,000 available, and we are wondering if this fits with your budget ideas.


We really liked the element of community composting and vermicomposting that you promoted. I wonder if it would be possible to include two types of composting options, to compare the two? Vermicomposting and also 'dry' composting? We can discuss more.


We also want to be clear about the level of monitoring and data gathering that this partnership will involve. This is because Re-Alliance is gathering data for a larger piece of work, creating guidelines for regenerative response in contexts of displacement. We can discuss this on the call, and want to make sure that you're comfortable with this.


Do you have time next Wednesday, 20th at 3pm Uganda time? (1pm UK time)

Would you like to include Stefanos in this call, who I know you applied alongside?


Many thanks, Paulinho! Looking forward to being in touch again.


James

text_entities.text:
Dear Paulinho,


It's a pleasure to be in touch with you. How are you? Thank you so much for your application in Re-Alliance's recent tendering process.


One of my colleagues may have been in touch to thank you for your application already. After review, we would like to move your application to the next stage of the process.


The next stage of the¬†process involves a call with me to discuss further. We have up to GBP¬£4,000 available, and we are wondering if this fits with your budget ideas.


We really liked the element of community composting and vermicomposting that you promoted. I wonder if it would be possible to include two types of composting options, to compare the two? Vermicomposting and also 'dry' composting? We can discuss more.


We also want to be clear about the level of monitoring and data gathering that this partnership will involve. This is because Re-Alliance is gathering data for a larger piece of work, creating guidelines for regenerative response in contexts of displacement. We can discuss this on the call, and want to make sure that you're comfortable with this.


Do you have time next Wednesday, 20th at 3pm Uganda time? (1pm UK time)

Would you like to include Stefanos in this call, who I know you applied alongside?


Many thanks, Paulinho! Looking forward to being in touch again.


James

text: good read

TL;DR 

Both vermicomposting and traditional composting will allow you to turn organic material into nutrient-rich soil. And both of them have their advantages. Traditional composting needs constant turning, but vermicomposting does not. Vermicomposting cannot manage large volumes of waste, but it is faster. Lastly, vermicomposting can be both outdoors and indoors, whereas traditional composting can be outdoors only. To sum up, vermicomposting has more benefits than traditional composting for most people but those with farms or large lots of land who need to compost significant amounts of food and yard debris will gain the most benefit from traditional composting.

I‚Äôve found that both serve their purpose. I continue to practice traditional composting during the warmer months because I can compost large amounts of food scraps. During the winter, however, the worm bin is the only one still producing nutrient-rich soil additives.

text_entities.text: good read
https://thrivingyard.com/vermicompost-vs-compost/

TL;DR 

Both vermicomposting and traditional composting will allow you to turn organic material into nutrient-rich soil. And both of them have their advantages. Traditional composting needs constant turning, but vermicomposting does not. Vermicomposting cannot manage large volumes of waste, but it is faster. Lastly, vermicomposting can be both outdoors and indoors, whereas traditional composting can be outdoors only. To sum up, vermicomposting has more benefits than traditional composting for most people but those with farms or large lots of land who need to compost significant amounts of food and yard debris will gain the most benefit from traditional composting.

I‚Äôve found that both serve their purpose. I continue to practice traditional composting during the warmer months because I can compost large amounts of food scraps. During the winter, however, the worm bin is the only one still producing nutrient-rich soil additives.

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
messages.text:
Hi James,

The total cost of the website is 1500 USD. Currently I am funding this from my own money. I do suggest we keep this out of the 4k budget (4794,48USD?). Therefore I wondered whether there is a chance for extra funding? In case we would indeed have to rely on the 4k, I would not go for more than 250$. 

Further assessment on budgeting still needs to be made of course. 

When I reflected with Paulinho, we realised that a relative location closer to the markets would not be financially viable with the current budget, as the cost of land is much higher. Secondly, we also need to consider transportation of water. So this vehicle would have multiple purposes.

text_entities.text:
Hi James,

The total cost of the website is 1500 USD. Currently I am funding this from my own money. I do suggest we keep this out of the 4k budget (4794,48USD?). Therefore I wondered whether there is a chance for extra funding? In case we would indeed have to rely on the 4k, I would not go for more than 250$. 

Further assessment on budgeting still needs to be made of course. 

When I reflected with Paulinho, we realised that a relative location closer to the markets would not be financially viable with the current budget, as the cost of land is much higher. Secondly, we also need to consider transportation of water. So this vehicle would have multiple purposes.

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
text: A blockchain-based platform that provides mobile banking services to refugee populations, where they can store their funds in cryptocurrencies, is one potential use case to address this challenge. One company doing this today is

Leaf makes use of USSD technology, and is accessible to anyone with a basic phone, regardless of if they have an internet connection. It allows you to store money and send it to friends and family safely and without banking fees, while allowing users to cash in and out using mobile money. It also enables individuals to send money in one currency and receive it in another. This is key as family and friends may be separated when fleeing and could end up in different countries using different currencies.

text_entities.text: A blockchain-based platform that provides mobile banking services to refugee populations, where they can store their funds in cryptocurrencies, is one potential use case to address this challenge. One company doing this today is
Leaf Global Fintech

Leaf makes use of USSD technology, and is accessible to anyone with a basic phone, regardless of if they have an internet connection. It allows you to store money and send it to friends and family safely and without banking fees, while allowing users to cash in and out using mobile money. It also enables individuals to send money in one currency and receive it in another. This is key as family and friends may be separated when fleeing and could end up in different countries using different currencies.

messages.text:
Unidos will construct 2 to 4 commercially sized vermicomposting production facilities spread around the 3 connecting neighboorhoods, and establish the logistics from gathering greenwaste as a resource, to the distribution and selling of worm compost to farmers. 

Unidos purpose is to built demonstration sites, and focus on teaching householders how to produce worm compost on a small scale by recycling their kitchen waste; show farmers the main benefits of using worm compost in comparison to chemical fertilisers, and why worm compost is superior; introduce people into the commercial production of worm compost, and demonstrate how to construct such facility. 

Why Vermicomposting? 

It might surprise us, but the worm is one of the most productive animals we can sustainably farm as a permaculture driven refugee initiative, to produce a healthy and rich fertiliser. 

Composting worms can eat up to 3x their own bodyweight per day, producing readily available plant nutrients. Their castings can contain almost all 16 essential elements for plant health. As well as plant growth hormones like gibberellins, a wide range of vitamins including B12, and nitrogen fixing microbes. Worm castings are so beneficial that compared to regular compost they can contain 1000 times more bacterial life. 

It also includes minerals such as nitrates, phosphorus, magnesium, potassium, calcium, manganese, copper, zinc, cobalt, borax, iron, carbon and nitrogen. Worm castings also contain enzymes and humus. 

It has at least 3 times more the amount of vital plant nutrients in readily available forms that are slowly released over time. The finished product is neutral pH of 7.0. 

It enhances plant growth by allowing the development of new shoots and leaves, resulting in increased productivity.

text_entities.text:
Unidos will construct 2 to 4 commercially sized vermicomposting production facilities spread around the 3 connecting neighboorhoods, and establish the logistics from gathering greenwaste as a resource, to the distribution and selling of worm compost to farmers. 

Unidos purpose is to built demonstration sites, and focus on teaching householders how to produce worm compost on a small scale by recycling their kitchen waste; show farmers the main benefits of using worm compost in comparison to chemical fertilisers, and why worm compost is superior; introduce people into the commercial production of worm compost, and demonstrate how to construct such facility. 

Why Vermicomposting? 

It might surprise us, but the worm is one of the most productive animals we can sustainably farm as a permaculture driven refugee initiative, to produce a healthy and rich fertiliser. 

Composting worms can eat up to 3x their own bodyweight per day, producing readily available plant nutrients. Their castings can contain almost all 16 essential elements for plant health. As well as plant growth hormones like gibberellins, a wide range of vitamins including B12, and nitrogen fixing microbes. Worm castings are so beneficial that compared to regular compost they can contain 1000 times more bacterial life. 

It also includes minerals such as nitrates, phosphorus, magnesium, potassium, calcium, manganese, copper, zinc, cobalt, borax, iron, carbon and nitrogen. Worm castings also contain enzymes and humus. 

It has at least 3 times more the amount of vital plant nutrients in readily available forms that are slowly released over time. The finished product is neutral pH of 7.0. 

It enhances plant growth by allowing the development of new shoots and leaves, resulting in increased productivity.

This question is actually simple.

Describe the environment

socially; (How you live?); is there any conflict, do people celebrate a lot? do people easily share activities? do you live on the land shared with others? 
economically; how much unemployment there is, how much opportunity there is, how you guys make a living
physically: are you healthy, can eat enough, sleep enough, see a doctor when needed,

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
messages.text:
Example:

Defiants helped seeding the first pilot and built confidence within the organisation that vermicomposting is a scaleable business model 

Re-alliance helped scaling to 2 more units, with anticipation to have direct impact on local community. Ensuring food security through regeneration of soil fertility. 

Socialimpactaward helped with incubating the business aspect solidifying a potential to scale to both commercialisation and reselling compost, and/or education program to teach others managing a vermicomposting unit

UNCHR funding helped scaling to an education facility to train vermicompost producers, and train them into business to re-sell the compost. 

Lush funding helped scaling to 10 more vermi units and establish a solid income stream for Unidos.

text_entities.text:

messages.text:
Question is, which road are we going with this?

I see 3 potentials:

- Vermicompost units to provide fertiliser to local families. (non profit)

- Education center: for farmers on how to use. For produces on how to produce and resell (non profit)

- Commercialisation scale and revenue stream for Unidos (for profit)

messages.text:
Training Metrics (Quantitative)
Numbers of participants per training
Numbers of training activities
Number of people who will be producing vermicompost
Number of people who we will be distributing vermicompost
Ecological Metrics (Quantitative)
Analysing structure of soil BEFORE and AFTER implementing (with Visual Soil Assessment like this)
Analysing organic materials present in soil BEFORE and AFTER
Visual tool with glass to see into the soil, transformation and spread of mycelium in soil
Soil Water Retention test - soil squeeze test BEFORE and AFTER (measuring ml of water retained in soil one day after watering. One handful of soil.)
Economic impacts (Quantitative and qualitative)
Household spending on food (baseline only, then changes after one and two seasons)
Social and Cultural Stories (Qualitative measurements)

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
messages.text:
Strategy could be:

Phase 1: charity as a revenue model supported by defiants and re-alliance

Phase 1 helps to master the teaching and the production of Vermicompost 

From this you will gather research, brand exposure and a reputation in the local agricultural economy. 

Talk about Why you chosen Vermicompost, how scaleable it currently is, how much farmers have shown interest into using it. 

(And reach the moment where farmers are actually producing healthy crops)

Phase 2: Vermicompost as a revenue model, locally production of Vermicompost.

Phase 2 is hard to imagine without data from phase 1. But raising the right questions would solidify your persuasion towards the jury.

How much vermicompost are we able to produce vs the demand?

How much will 1kg of Vermicompost cost?

How much kg is needed to fertilise land?

How much unfertilised land is there? 

Can farmers afford it? 

Which farmers are you firstly gonna pull into your 

Are there farmers who are more wealthy?

What is your marketing strategy?

‚Äî

These questions can maybe be answered with guessing but are not yet a priority until your production is successful. 

Moral of the situation is to Master the worms and the teaching first. Only then you will have value that can translate into economic relevance

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
messages.text:
And you can be vulnerable and honest about things you are still uncertain about. 

Authentic communication goes a lot further

To sum up:

Be Exited about what you reached
And hopeful about what you want to reach.

Narrative could sound like this:

‚ÄúIm excited how much farmers have shown to our classes.

I hope we can reach as much farmers as possible. Currently they spend xxx$ on chemical fertilisers, if they shift that to Vermicompost it could turn the tide and regenerate the depleted soil in Nakivale.

Data proofs that soils do much better.
And it is that scientific evidence that drives me to pursue Vermicompost as the main element to secure food production for the next decades.‚Äù

Here you clearly state the WHY, as you emphasise your emotional connection to this mission and vision.

text:
What can today's managers learn from street-kids?

In this book, Arnoud Raskin tells the powerful story of the organization Mobile School (
) and the company StreetwiZe (

). Together, Mobile School and StreetwiZe form a hybrid organization, where the profits that are generated by StreetwiZe are used to advance the social goals of Mobile School.

This book is also the inspirational story of Arnoud Raskin himself. For many years, Raskin has worked with street-kids all over the world. One of his first experiences, when he had just arrived in Colombia, showed him one of the best ways to help these street-kids: By boosting their self esteem. At the time, Raskin didn't speak any Spanish, and asked a street-kid to help him out. Raskin started drawing things, and asked the kid, who was now his teacher, to give him the corresponding word in Spanish. Thus a drawing of a house became casa, a bird became p√°jaro. Raskin noticed that his young teacher was completely concentrated for an hour and a half, very different from the concentration span these street-kids usually had when they participated in learning activities: Typically, after about 5 minutes, they tended to lose interest. This first observation was followed some days later by another, when Raskin asked another kid to be his teacher. At some moment, his previous teacher showed up, and the 2 street-kids started a quarrel, with the first teacher claiming he was the teacher. Raskin realized ''that by placing the kid in the position of teacher and thus reverse the power relations, the kid became aware of his possibilities and all of a sudden managed to persevere much longer. By chance I had placed the kid in a position of power and that resulted in a clear positive impact on his self esteem and on his actions and capabilities'' (pag 45).

Raskin's own observations where confirmed and complemented with what he read about empowerment in the works of Paulo Freire. The books opens with a quote from Freire:

''Leaders who do not act dialogically, but insist on imposing their decisions, do not organize the people ‚Äì they manipulate them.

They do not liberate, nor are they liberated: they oppress''.

Building on this observation that improving their self esteem is one of the best ways to help the street-kids, Raskin designed the Mobile School, a learning tool on wheels with blackboards and educational games. Raskin realised that to increase the street-kids' self esteem, to really empower them, he had to meet them in their environment. So he started to take his Mobile School into the streets to help the kids in the settings they were most familiar with.

Raskin also realised that his Mobile Schools could help with offering street-kids better chances to leave their life on the street behind. It turns out that typically only 10 percent of the street-kids who are taken in to a shelter (run by NGOs or government) manage to stay off the streets. The vast majority falls back and returns to the street. How is it possible that so many prefer the street to the (relative) comfort of those well-meaning shelters? It turns out that the few who do make it, are intrinsically motivated to change their life. Their high self esteem allows them to see the opportunity and make a positive choice to go for it.

What are the characteristics of the winners of the street, and of those who manage to leave the life on the street behind? Raskin, with the help of others, found that those winners tended to have 4 competencies:
- Positive Focus
- Resilience and Agility
- Proactive Creativity
- Cooperative Competition

What can today's managers learn from street-kids?

In this book, Arnoud Raskin tells the powerful story of the organization Mobile School (
www.mobileschool.org/en
) and the company StreetwiZe (
www.streetwize.be

). Together, Mobile School and StreetwiZe form a hybrid organization, where the profits that are generated by StreetwiZe are used to advance the social goals of Mobile School.

This book is also the inspirational story of Arnoud Raskin himself. For many years, Raskin has worked with street-kids all over the world. One of his first experiences, when he had just arrived in Colombia, showed him one of the best ways to help these street-kids: By boosting their self esteem. At the time, Raskin didn't speak any Spanish, and asked a street-kid to help him out. Raskin started drawing things, and asked the kid, who was now his teacher, to give him the corresponding word in Spanish. Thus a drawing of a house became casa, a bird became p√°jaro. Raskin noticed that his young teacher was completely concentrated for an hour and a half, very different from the concentration span these street-kids usually had when they participated in learning activities: Typically, after about 5 minutes, they tended to lose interest. This first observation was followed some days later by another, when Raskin asked another kid to be his teacher. At some moment, his previous teacher showed up, and the 2 street-kids started a quarrel, with the first teacher claiming he was the teacher. Raskin realized ''that by placing the kid in the position of teacher and thus reverse the power relations, the kid became aware of his possibilities and all of a sudden managed to persevere much longer. By chance I had placed the kid in a position of power and that resulted in a clear positive impact on his self esteem and on his actions and capabilities'' (pag 45).

Raskin's own observations where confirmed and complemented with what he read about empowerment in the works of Paulo Freire. The books opens with a quote from Freire:

''Leaders who do not act dialogically, but insist on imposing their decisions, do not organize the people ‚Äì they manipulate them.

They do not liberate, nor are they liberated: they oppress''.

Building on this observation that improving their self esteem is one of the best ways to help the street-kids, Raskin designed the Mobile School, a learning tool on wheels with blackboards and educational games. Raskin realised that to increase the street-kids' self esteem, to really empower them, he had to meet them in their environment. So he started to take his Mobile School into the streets to help the kids in the settings they were most familiar with.

Raskin also realised that his Mobile Schools could help with offering street-kids better chances to leave their life on the street behind. It turns out that typically only 10 percent of the street-kids who are taken in to a shelter (run by NGOs or government) manage to stay off the streets. The vast majority falls back and returns to the street. How is it possible that so many prefer the street to the (relative) comfort of those well-meaning shelters? It turns out that the few who do make it, are intrinsically motivated to change their life. Their high self esteem allows them to see the opportunity and make a positive choice to go for it.

What are the characteristics of the winners of the street, and of those who manage to leave the life on the street behind? Raskin, with the help of others, found that those winners tended to have 4 competencies:
- Positive Focus
- Resilience and Agility
- Proactive Creativity
- Cooperative Competition

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
messages.text:
Raskin realised that these competencies are also valuable for today's managers in the competitive business world:
- Positive focus: The street-kids who are winners have a positive view on life. A positive attitude allows them to recognise opportunities and is indispensable for survival. And those winners of the street take responsibility. They don't blame others or external circumstances for the situation they are in.
- Resilience and Agility (Veerkracht en Wendbaarheid): Winners of the street know how to deal with setbacks and how to overcome obstacles. They have the flexibility to adapt to new circumstances and to go for new opportunities.
- Proactive Creativity: Winners of the street have the right attitude take risks and to go for their idea and make the best of it.
- Cooperative Competition. They know when to compete and when to cooperate.

These 4 street skills became the basis for Raskin's company StreetwiZe. Using the 4 street skills, StreetwiZe helps today's managers to implement change projects in their organizations, to offer personal development (from senior executives to young potentials), to shift the company culture to make the employers more positive, resilient and agile, and to offer the company, its employees, customers and other stakeholders meaning and purpose.

Together, StreetwiZe and Mobile Schools form a hybrid organization, focused on offering value to both StreetwiZe's corporate clients and to Mobile School's clients, i.e. the street-kids and the local partners who use the Mobile Schools. All the profits of StreetwiZe are used to finance the social impact projects of Mobile School. In the hybrid organization, pursuing financial profit and pursuing social impact support each other.

I found this book to be very inspirational. It contains Arnoud Raskin's powerful life story, which is inseparable from Mobile School's and StreetwiZe's. But beyond that, the book is even much more than a autobiography or a business case on how to build a hybrid organization.

For me, one of the most important take-aways of this book are its lessons on how motivation works. Raskin's ideas are similar to those expressed by Daniel Pink in his book Drive. Pink mentions that there are 3 types of intrinsic motivation that get us going: Autonomy, Mastery and Purpose. On many pages, Raskin stresses the importance of purpose (zingeving). He cites Paulo Freire: ''When you offer people purpose and recognition, they will start to develop themselves'' (pag 45). He also observes: ''In order to attract new talented employees, and to keep the actual employees motivated, you need to offer authentic purpose. If you don't offer a higher purpose, then your employees will look for that somewhere else. When it comes to customers, it is also crucial to offer a convincing answer to purpose question'' (pag 31).

Throughout the book, there are also many useful observations on innovation and thinking out of the box: ''If you want to innovate, you can not start with the na√Øve hope that you will get immediate applause for your new idea. If you do happen to get immediate applause, that probably means you are still inside the box. If you are really going outside the box, you'll have to be prepared to face resistance and you'll have to be willing to fight for your idea. Who expects a red carpet for his new idea, is na√Øve and is likely to be disappointed'' (pag 53).

Too bad this book, for the moment, is only available in Dutch. It deserves a far wider audience than the Dutch language can provide.

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
text: Commons-oriented peer production can be defined as any process whereby individuals can freely and openly contribute to a common pool (of knowledge, code, and design), necessarily coupled to forms of participatory governance (since there is no relation of dependence between free contributors); and thereby create a common pool of knowledge that is itself open to new contributions. Hence we get, by analogy with the circulation of capital, a 'circulation of the commons', that insures the reproduction of the commons itself.  On the side of 'immaterial production' (which of course itself rests on a material infrastructure), this model has been rapidly emerging in the fields of the production of free software (open source software), open design, and open hardware. This type of peer production allows for massive parallel development of immaterial knowledge and an open flow of technical, social and technical evolution.

text.text: An example of it would be the open agricultural communities such as AdaBio Construction in France, which share the design of agricultural machine designs for eco-agriculture, and similar projects in the Anglo-Saxon world, such as the Slow Tools project, Farm Hack, the Open Tech Collaborative, and Open Source Ecology.

Hence we get, by analogy with the circulation of capital, a 'circulation of the commons', that insures the reproduction of the commons itself.  On the side of 'immaterial production' (which of course itself rests on a material infrastructure), this model has been rapidly emerging in the fields of the production of free software (open source software), open design, and open hardware. This type of peer production allows for massive parallel development of immaterial knowledge and an open flow of technical, social and technical evolution.

An example of it would be the open agricultural communities such as AdaBio Construction in France, which share the design of agricultural machine designs for eco-agriculture, and similar projects in the Anglo-Saxon world, such as the Slow Tools project, Farm Hack, the Open Tech Collaborative, and Open Source Ecology.

Hey Gino,
Here is my thoughts ,correct me where i am wrong 
To reach our major goal of promoting food security in Nakivale, there 3 important steps that we should follow :
Soil regeneration; As we know, the soil in Nakivale is unfertile and eroded, this is where vermicomposting plays an important role in healing and regenerating the soil, but this won't stop us while educating and demonstrating to people or farmers different methods of making compost, such as dry compost, etc‚Ä¶
Practicing and educating people about regenerative agriculture: after being able to regenerate our soil, we need to test it by applying different regenerative agricultural designs or practices to shift from traditional agriculture to a regenerative one, demonstrating the difference between monoculture and polyculture, the importance of crops rotation and its contribution to maintaining a productive soil 
Shifting from consumption food to business growing

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
messages.text:
When you add organic matter to your compost it begins to decompose. This rotting process happens thanks to the work of millions of helpful microbes which feed off the raw materials and slowly transform them into compost.

But these helpful little critters also need air to function properly.

This is where ‚Äúturning‚Äù becomes useful.

In the beginning, compost includes plenty of space for air to circulate. As you add more things to your compost, the weight compresses the layers of organic matter and the air pockets shrink.

Turning (sometimes referred to as aerating) helps introduce air back into the pile.

Also, composting materials tend to decompose at different rates throughout the pile. In general, the core of the heap tends to heat up quickly at the beginning of the process. As the microbes get to work, they generate heat and use up any available oxygen.

Turning the compost allows you to transfer undepleted organic material back into the mix so the fast-acting microorganisms can carry on their work.

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
messages.text:
Soil regeneration is a holistic practice involving different soil improvement methodologies.

Currently, we are researching the use of vermicomposting to enable the production of highly nutritious fertilizer which is directly bio-available for plant roots.

But to improve soil structure, even more, we will also introduce effective dry composting methods with the use of composting tumblers (cylinder tanks) which limits labor intensity to aerate the composting process, this method also speeds up the production and in the time increases the quantity of biomass. This biomass helps to improve soil structure, prevent erosion and retain water.

Another essential aspect is the introduction of mulching with organic materials. Where we add a thick layer of organic carbon materials like wood chunks or straw to support several functions; water conservation, micro life improvement, weed prevention, and erosion prevention.

text_entities.text:
Soil regeneration is a holistic practice involving different soil improvement methodologies.

Currently, we are researching the use of vermicomposting to enable the production of highly nutritious fertilizer which is directly bio-available for plant roots.

But to improve soil structure, even more, we will also introduce effective dry composting methods with the use of composting tumblers (cylinder tanks) which limits labor intensity to aerate the composting process, this method also speeds up the production and in the time increases the quantity of biomass. This biomass helps to improve soil structure, prevent erosion and retain water.

Another essential aspect is the introduction of mulching with organic materials. Where we add a thick layer of organic carbon materials like wood chunks or straw to support several functions; water conservation, micro life improvement, weed prevention, and erosion prevention.

How many times did you re-film each person?

I like the settings, and the diversity of people talking. But I think you need better help with montaging and script. 

It feels like they are not sure about what they are saying. You can tell they are nervous about being in front of a camera. It could help to read about how to prepare this, im sure on the internet there is plenty of tips on how to do a proper intro video (crowd funding platforms facilitate this as well)

How to prepare yourself to talk in front of the camera.
Articulating their wording better from a sense of being just like you talk to your parent when you explain the project form your heart and not your mind. Y

You guys are not talking to a camera but to other people. 

Also the video montage is not according to professional standards. maybe we need to find help for that as well. The logo appearing in the beginning is something that can be removed.

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
messages.text:
Also you look closed, your hands are crossed, your head inside the shoulders... making you seem smaller than you can be...

Again, I understand it is challenging to be in front of an audience or camera. But when you were talking to me you dont seem like that... you are self assured and passionate.. so that is what i am missing in this video... maybe you think you need to act, while actually you simply need to be yourself

Perhaps it will help to do breathwork sessions before the shooting so you feel deeply relaxed and more into your body and less in your mind

text:
Dear Gino Ludikhuyze

UNIDOS SOCIAL INNOVATION CENTER is currently being considered for the 2023 LUSH Spring Prize shortlist. We are contacting you as you have been named as a referee by Paulinho Muzaliwa.


The LUSH Spring Prize is a prize for projects working towards environmental and social regeneration. Please see

for more information. UNIDOS SOCIAL INNOVATION CENTER is being considered in the Permaculture Magazine Award prize category.

In
, (or a

video or audio recording), please could you tell us:
¬†¬†¬†¬†1. Your name
¬†¬†¬†¬†2. What is your link to UNIDOS SOCIAL INNOVATION CENTER?
¬†¬†¬†¬†3. In what capacity have you worked with them?
¬†¬†¬†¬†4. Based on your link/work, why would you recommend them for a Spring Prize?

Please provide us with your reference by Wednesday 9th November 2022.

We look forward to hearing from you.

Warmest wishes,
Francesca

messages.from: Paulinho
text:
Hello Paulinho Muzaliwa

Thank you for your application to the Lush Spring Prize 2023!

We are currently considering your project for the Spring Prize 2023 shortlist pending our due diligence process.

We noticed that UNIDOS SOCIAL INNOVATION CENTER may be involved in farming animals. This will not prevent you from being shortlisted but please could you provide the following:
Clarification on if or how your project is related to animal farming
Some information on how you manage the welfare of animals (does not need to be more than 100 words)
A statement confirming that, should you be awarded a prize, the money would not go directly towards the slaughter of animals.
Please could you respond with this information by the end of¬†

We will be in touch shortly after to confirm whether UNIDOS SOCIAL INNOVATION CENTER has been shortlisted and to let you know the next steps.

Many thanks!

Warmest wishes,
Fran

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
text:
My personal plan since 10 years was to develop a for-profit and non-profit or hybrid organisation.

I am a permaculture designer who is doing his research in design thinking for refugee settlements.

And I am digital marketing specialist who runs his own¬†business for blockchain startups.

I met Paul when he was active in a blockchain project.

At the time they were in instant need for funding to protect unfinished construction site from the rain season.

I setup¬†a crowdfund with the team of

and collected 5k seed funding to finish the building serving now as unidos education center.

To get a better idea i spend 1 month in uganda and 2 weeks in nakivale, where i setup¬†a local connection with kcca (governmental and UN funded permaculture education center in Kampala) to learn about vermicomposting

Since then I am involved as consultant of the Unidosteam, developed their website
, and supported in several marketing efforts.

is still funding the project monthly 800$ to keep operations going to pay for wages for the teachers

Since the beginning I am involved I saw with great amazement how smooth the executions went

As Unidos has a impact & business oriented attitude, and also expertise to manage funding and realise construction and organisation of human resources

I consider this is as one of the few permaculture projects that is actually succeeding in nakivale and maybe also Uganda. A professor who works for Kampala university as researcher in ecological development told me not many permaculture projects were happening.¬†

With support with our network we were able to bring unidos in the spotlight, their community and reach is substantial, which supports addressing a direct urgency for a growing crisis to come.

¬†Therefor you have my recommendation to support unidosprojects

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
text:
Hi,

Thanks for your inquiry.

The only animals that are involved are composting worms. And it is to everyone's interest including these creatures that they are held in nurturing conditions to help us produce the compost.

Such conditions are; Quiet, Shaded, with stable temperatures; Not too hot and not too cold, balanced consistency of the organic materials that are fed to the worms; Not too moist and not too dry, balanced PH, is oxygenated.

We regularly take samples to measure these conditions. So the worms can thrive in an healthy environment. 

While worms get fed organic waste from markets and households nearby we mix it with carbon materials such as bark, wood snips and cardboard, the worms in turn provide highly nutrient-rich worm castings, which eventually will support us in regeneration of the depleted soils in and around the refugee settlements.¬†

It is a common practice in regenerative agriculture to use composting worms.¬†

text.text: A statement confirming that, should you be awarded a prize, the money would not go directly towards the slaughter of animals.

text: We do not support, teach or practice slaughtering of animals in our education center for regenerative agriculture.

Hi,

Thanks for your inquiry.

The only animals that are involved are composting worms. And it is to everyone's interest including these creatures that they are held in nurturing conditions to help us produce the compost.

Such conditions are; Quiet, Shaded, with stable temperatures; Not too hot and not too cold, balanced consistency of the organic materials that are fed to the worms; Not too moist and not too dry, balanced PH, is oxygenated.

We regularly take samples to measure these conditions. So the worms can thrive in an healthy environment. 

While worms get fed organic waste from markets and households nearby we mix it with carbon materials such as bark, wood snips and cardboard, the worms in turn provide highly nutrient-rich worm castings, which eventually will support us in regeneration of the depleted soils in and around the refugee settlements.¬†

It is a common practice in regenerative agriculture to use composting worms.¬†
A statement confirming that, should you be awarded a prize, the money would not go directly towards the slaughter of animals.
We do not support, teach or practice slaughtering of animals in our education center for regenerative agriculture.

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
text: In  the  current  process  of  producing  vermicompost  on  a  large-scale,  the  main

challenge  is  to  keep  the  worms  alive.  This  is  achieved  by  maintaining  temperature  and 
moisture in their living medium. It is a difficult task to maintain these parameters throughout 
the process.  Currently, this is  achieved by building infrastructure  but this method requires a 
large initial investment and  long-run maintenance. Also, these  methods are limited to small-
scale production. For large-scale production, a unit is developed which utilises natural airflow 
with water and automation.  The main aim of  this unit  is to provide favourable conditions to 
worms in large-scale production with very low investment and minimum maintenance in long 
term. The key innovation  of  this research  is that  the technology  used in  the unit  should be 
practical and  easy  to adopt by small farmers.  For long-term  maintenance of  the technology 
lesser number of parts are used

messages.from: Paulinho
messages.text:
Here are some of what we came up with 
Hey guys take a look on these questions, I think they will be helpful if we want to ask participants and gather data or make a good video with quality content .

 What inspired you to pursue permaculture training?

How has your understanding of permaculture changed since taking the training?

Can you give an example of a permaculture principle that you find 
particularly impactful?

How has the training influenced your approach to gardening or agriculture?

Can you describe a personal project or experience in which you applied permaculture principles?

In what ways has permaculture training influenced your lifestyle choices?

How has the permaculture community affected your life since taking the training?

Can you share any challenges or obstacles you faced during your permaculture journey?

How has permaculture training impacted your relationships with others and the environment?

What advice would you give to someone considering taking permaculture training?

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
messages.text:
Start Long term (1-3 years prior cultivation or crops) 

Detect what challenges there are:

Erosion due to water run off?
Poor soil; ph, lack of organic material)?
Too much wind?
Lack of shade?

Then start with solutions that create humus over time

Digging Swales on contour lines prevent erosion 
Mulch the holes to prevent evaporation
Plant drought resistant perennial trees and bush to create microclimates to create natural shade
apply polyculture or agro forestry principles making sure companion planting is established 

to speed up the process

Add Drip irrigation systems
Attach shades (canvas in the air) to prevent sun evaporate water
Bring in compost
Add card board where ever possible as ground cover

messages.text:
A crowdfunding video should include the following elements:
 1 An introduction: Start by introducing yourself and your project to viewers.
 2 The problem: Explain the problem that your project aims to solve.
 3 The solution: Describe how your project solves the problem and the benefits it provides.
 4 The team: Introduce the team behind the project and their qualifications.
 5 Visuals: Use visuals, such as images, animation, or footage, to illustrate your project and make it more engaging.
 6 Call-to-action: Encourage viewers to support your project by including a clear call-to-action directing them to your crowdfunding page.

messages.text:
first impressions, there was too much about fertilizers. I think it would feel more emphaty if you would show in the first part more starving people. of course it's important to not do like like cheap soap TV show but I felt like it wasn't enough I would like to see maybe some special story. it shouldn‚Äôt be too much cause it can feels like manipulation even if you are showing true. that's why I would be careful with showing starving people, children, their food what they have on breakfast and etc. but I felt like emotional part in the start wasn‚Äôt strong enough. 
 so if I would edit this video again, if I tried to fix it, I would leave the base the same, I would not change the audio track, I would just add more moments with people who are victims in this situation. frames would alternate with cultivation, emotional frame, cultivation, emotional frame, guy's monologue, emotional frame guy againsomething like this 
 so the point to make people watching till the end because the end is important it's about the donation so maybe I'm thinking like director because I have this education but I think it works everywhere the same

messages.text:
I think our vision and ambition align. 

You have a talented content and social media marketing team on the ground.

We have a case study in development.

The technical foundation to have at least a conservative agency is present, to support local African initiatives which lack resources to market themselves to attain funds.

In other words it is scaleable non profit business model.

We simply need to calculate what our cost would be to run it, make a livelihood from it. And how we can get better recognition by vetted organisations, which help us facilitate transparency as a legitimate third world regeneration agency for refugee settlements.

- Have potentially approval of local government 
- Why refugees (Unidos) know best what other refugees need.

- How it will be marketed

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
text:
Existing middleman parties dont provide continuation for seeded projects. 

Projects have to keep applying again for money but dont always have the money. 

It is in conflict with the regenerative business model.

Collection of funds by local organisation (Umbrella working closely with following up organisation. 

Our aim is to ensure that funds are managed by a middleman who is active on a local level, but also to ensure the followup results in long term impact and resilience. 

Enabling economy inclusion for the follow up Organisation on a commercial level and become independant from donations. 

In short: Make unidos economically self sufficient. 


‚Äî

text_entities.text: Problem statement

Existing middleman parties dont provide continuation for seeded projects. 

Projects have to keep applying again for money but dont always have the money. 

It is in conflict with the regenerative business model.
Solution statement

Collection of funds by local organisation (Umbrella working closely with following up organisation. 

Our aim is to ensure that funds are managed by a middleman who is active on a local level, but also to ensure the followup results in long term impact and resilience. 

Enabling economy inclusion for the follow up Organisation on a commercial level and become independant from donations. 

In short: Make unidos economically self sufficient. 


‚Äî

messages.text:
Another fact is most of food produced in Nakivale are consumed in Urban area , as result food is remain expensive on the market here in the settlement because most of food that we buy are coming from Urban after being manufacturing, this is an example of maize.
Something that can be a solution is to make a community food bank which are the most consumed and produced here.
The idea is when we are in a harvesting period , for us we buy from farmers who want to sell their products then stock them until when the next farming circle will start , the time that everyone need Seeds , or want to buy food on the market , this will be a great time that we can start selling and make profits but to an affordable price .

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
text:
You mean a non profit way of reselling food + seeds? 

It actually could work if you would setup a farmers ‚Äúcooperative‚Äù. Im pretty sure such models already exist in third world countries. See:

Small scale farmers would work with an intermediant who buys up all the crops, securing the farmer‚Äôs existence, the quality of the crop, and a reasonable price for the consumer. 

‚Äî

Conventionally this happens in Europe: The bigsale market works with farmers by buying their crops, where merchants; those who run grocery stores or restaurants, buy the produce from the bigsale market, at a discounted price (Without tax).

> Here the bigsale market is the middleman

There is another method to protect farmers (which is the ‚Äúfrom farm to table‚Äù or p2p principle) and secure food availability called CSA (Community supported agriculture). Which happens mostly with ecologically cultivated food. 

> Here there is no middleman but there is a platform and association facilitating the direct relation between farmer and consumer (Something that became back a trend in Europe)

People buy a 1 year membership with the farmer, and each week they can pick up basket of harvested crops availably that season.

Benefits: 

1) The year membership allows cheaper organically and locally grown food for the consumer for as long the seasons permit it.
2) The year membership protects the farmer financially

The only problem is, that if the crop fail the consumer also wont have food. 

‚Äî

text_entities.text:
You mean a non profit way of reselling food + seeds? 

It actually could work if you would setup a farmers ‚Äúcooperative‚Äù. Im pretty sure such models already exist in third world countries. See:
https://www.un.org/esa/socdev/documents/2014/coopsegm/Sifa--Coops%20and%20agric%20dev.pdf

Small scale farmers would work with an intermediant who buys up all the crops, securing the farmer‚Äôs existence, the quality of the crop, and a reasonable price for the consumer. 

‚Äî

Conventionally this happens in Europe: The bigsale market works with farmers by buying their crops, where merchants; those who run grocery stores or restaurants, buy the produce from the bigsale market, at a discounted price (Without tax).

> Here the bigsale market is the middleman

There is another method to protect farmers (which is the ‚Äúfrom farm to table‚Äù or p2p principle) and secure food availability called CSA (Community supported agriculture). Which happens mostly with ecologically cultivated food. 

> Here there is no middleman but there is a platform and association facilitating the direct relation between farmer and consumer (Something that became back a trend in Europe)

People buy a 1 year membership with the farmer, and each week they can pick up basket of harvested crops availably that season.

Benefits: 

1) The year membership allows cheaper organically and locally grown food for the consumer for as long the seasons permit it.
2) The year membership protects the farmer financially

The only problem is, that if the crop fail the consumer also wont have food. 

‚Äî

- Road and access
- Nearest water source
- Max and low temperatures month to month
- Altitude (hight above sealevel)

- Wind directions

messages.text:
We can use this thesis as our problem statement to found the EU NGO, and Unidos as the case study we want to scale into other developing regions, not limited to refugee settlements, but to vulnerable communities in general.

The premise is to use incubation supporting local entrepreneurial and leadership talent by consistently funding and training within 3-5 years, to a point the business model is self sufficient. This enables economic inclusion, providing job opportunity for less fortunate (young mothers), and less talented (unschooled) youth.

This enables economic inclusion, providing job opportunity for less fortunate (young mothers), and less talented (unschooled) youth.

text:
I think the following 5 fit in Unidos longterm program:

Program 1)
Program 2)

Program 3) 

Incubation entrepreneurs > ~Youth empowerment 

Program 4)

Soil regeneration > resilient agriculture 

Program 5)

Women empowerment > resilient communities

Resilient communities being the end product and vision. 

But the foundation is hosted by financial and economic inclusion which can be seen as vehicle and the mission. In other words, without Economic inclusion there can hardly be a resilient community.

Until now it is all bootstrapped thanks to charity‚Ä¶ But as we know charity does not solve the problems faced on the long term.

text_entities.text:
I think the following 5 fit in Unidos longterm program:

Program 1)
Financial inclusion (banking unbanked) > Economic inclusion
Program 2)
Cooperativism > Common sharing of resources

Program 3) 

Incubation entrepreneurs > ~Youth empowerment 

Program 4)

Soil regeneration > resilient agriculture 

Program 5)

Women empowerment > resilient communities

Resilient communities being the end product and vision. 

But the foundation is hosted by financial and economic inclusion which can be seen as vehicle and the mission. In other words, without Economic inclusion there can hardly be a resilient community.

Until now it is all bootstrapped thanks to charity‚Ä¶ But as we know charity does not solve the problems faced on the long term.

messages.text:
Traditional humanitarian assistance ‚Äúcannot keep pace‚Äù with today‚Äôs soaring and complex hunger demands without simultaneously addressing their root causes, says WFP East Africa Senior Advisor Sibi Lawson-Marriott. She specializes in food systems and the closely entwined issues of climate action, resilience building and women‚Äôs empowerment.
‚ÄúWe need a new approach,‚Äù Lawson-Marriott adds, at a time when hunger is fueled by a mix of factors, including conflict, biodiversity loss, supply shocks and the growing climate crisis. ‚ÄúOtherwise, we‚Äôre not going to be able to fulfill our mandate of zero hunger. And the world badly needs us to do that.‚Äù

accidently edited the message, but what i meant was can you give a bit more data such as: 

- how many communities supported so far
- how many people graduated
- the impact of what you been doing so far?

- Before and after pictures 

- Amount of harvest
- Amount of vermicompost created
- How many worms have you grown, how many new colonies have you started?

- facts why refugee 4 refugee bears more results
- facts why other sustainable development fails in Nakivale and Unidos succeeds? 

‚Äî

All of the above needs tobe proven by evidence

‚Äî

My main question is, do you keep any data on progress? Because by now each new activity looks the same as any other previous activity, and it does not give the impression you are making progress. Meaning, your content starts to become boring or irrelevant. Especially to the audience on linked in. 

Where do you keep the data you need to collect for Re-Alliance?

text.text: Why does the nominee deserve recognition?

text:
As A young Congolese refugee, Paulinho was faced with a loss of a future, like many more refugees. He arrived with nothing in Nakivale. But was inspired to give everything. Not many believed him, the first 2 years were challenging. 

But determination enabled him to become an educator, a coach, a human rights activist, an environmentalist, and most of all a change maker who understands that the best way to help the displaced is by being displaced. 

 As an avid advocate in "Refugees for Refugees"; he trained more than 1500 people in regenerative agriculture to combat the threat of malnutrition in the largest refugee settlement in the world, Nakivale. 

More than farming alone he is training people, youth and women, to enable them the empowerment to make things happen, in business, in community, in family, and while doing he connects all nations behind one single cause; to end hunger in Nakivale.

We are enabling refugees to shifting from dependency on Humanitarian aids and  start taking care of the soil by applying worm compost, and planting trees to mitigate the change of our micro climates, creating an ideal environment to cultivate crops in return we are improving  the livelihood of refugees a hopeless place where Forty four percent (44%)

social networks. And most livelihood depends on humanitarian aid

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
messages.text:
Nakivale is a rather hopeless place, where 44% are unemployed due to a lack of skills, or because of the rigid education system and limited social networks, most, with a majority of women, depend on humanitarian aid.

Also, Uganda's national language is English and most refugees come from non-English speaking countries, breaking the language barrier by teaching refugees English is crucial to ensure economic participation.  

Therefore Paulinho started with founding an organization called Unidos, to train and teach people in business, leadership, and English.  

However, once it became clear that UNHCR was not able to finance refugees a food package of 3$/month, and most could not afford more than 1 meal per day. All while global food prices skyrocketed, dry season prolonged, soil eroded and thus crops kept failing, and a big increase of refugees migrating to Nakivale; he decided to dedicate his efforts to training people in regenerative agriculture. 

Committed to designing human systems that co-evolve in relation to their natural environment, Unidos enabled refugees to shift from dependency on humanitarian aid to start taking care of the soil. 

By using worms they are now able to produce rich fertilizer from the food waste of local markets. And together with planting trees, mitigating and shaping microclimates, they have created an ideal environment to cultivate crops. 

In return, it allowed mutual benefits and a greater expression of a resilient refugee.

Of the more than 1500 refugees Unidos trained in the last 3 years, 60% are growing organic food to sustain their families and 20% are producing and commercializing organic fertilizer to generate income addressing some of their basic needs; clean water, health care, schooling for their children.

Another vital part of community building in Nakivale is the empowerment of women. So far 1000 women were supported; and involved in the planting of 5000 trees (medical and food trees), launched as a campaign to tackle climate change. The leaves of the trees are used in soap making. Until now 700 Litres were produced of which 300 Litres were sold on local markets.

Overall his organization promotes inclusion and hosts communities by co-creating an open learning space to invest, learn, and identify the pressing issues and challenges in the life of many refugees. Paulinho helps them to come up with solutions, taking power in their own hands, instead of being subject to the unpredictable future ahead.

We started with Unidos without any support,
We have been laying bricks and sell them  then  the money we got , been used of operations cost of our small organization , we have been empowering each other   without knowing what we gonna eat in our families for 2 year until Defiants has find in us this motivation of doing something that can last change the entire refugee settlement and be able to provide us with adequate resources , operation cost and help us to build a safe space of educational purpose where we are co-creating opportunities for ourselves that is impacting both refugees and host communities

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
text:
Paulinho and the people he involved (other Congolese refugees), started with Unidos without any governmental (apart from some land that was donated by the Ugandan office of the prime minister) or other NGO support.

He and his team started by making mud bricks and selling them. With the money, they were able to cover operational costs which enabled them to give lectures and offer free meals to those who participated.

For the first 2 years, they had been encouraging each other without much clarity on what food they and their families would eat. 

This continued until me (Gino) and Paulinho met each other in an online community in October 2021. Paulinho was interested in how blockchain could financially emancipate refugees. 

At the time I was running a marketing agency in the blockchain industry. My dream was always to support a local refugee-led project. And with my background in regenerative agriculture, me and Paulinho discovered a complementary vision.

At the time we met, they had a half-constructed building, destined to become an education center, which they had built with self-made mud bricks on the land donated by the local government. This construction was threatened to crumble by heavy rains during the monsoon season. 

Within a month I was able to gather enough funding to help finalize the construction. And after 3 months I visited the location and I was permitted to enter the refugee settlement, as a teacher in regenerative agriculture. 

This marked a milestone for both Paulinho's
and my own organization

. 

From there I helped him with setting up a strategy for scaling his agriculture initiative, anything related to digital marketing, the administration required to employ teachers, and a monthly fee to cover operational costs and pay for the teachers, donated by my organization. 

Within a year Unidos was flourishing and gained international recognition from NGO's supporting refugee-led initiatives.

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
text:
Defiants co-founder Gino Ludikhuyze met Paul when he was active in a blockchain project. At the time, they were in instant need for funding to protect the unfinished construction site from the rain season. 

Gino immediately set up a crowdfund with the team of

and within 3 weeks time collected $5k in seed funding to finish the building serving now as Unidos education center.

To get a better personal impression I spent up to 1 month in Uganda, of which 2 weeks in Nakivale, where I helped establish a local connection with KCCA (governmental and UN-funded permaculture education center in Kampala) to direct Unidos learning about vermicomposting and other regenerative food cultivation systems.

Since then, Defiants co-founder Gino has been involved as a consultant of the Unidos team, where he supported various marketing executions such as developing Unidos website

is still funding the project monthly 800$ to keep operations going to pay for wages for the teachers.¬†

Since the beginning Defiants was involved, we saw with great amazement how smoothly the executions went, which left a satisfying feeling of cooperating with Paul and his team. 

The progress we have been logging in our Telegram news update channel¬†

As Unidos has an impact & business-oriented attitude, and also expertise to manage budgets and realise the construction and organization of human resources, I consider Unidos as one of the few permaculture projects that is actually succeeding in Nakivale refugee settlement. A professor who works for Kampala university as researcher in ecological development told me not many permaculture projects were successfully happening in refugee settlements. 

With the support from our network, we were able to bring Unidos in the spotlight. Therefore their community and reach are significantly large. This reach supports indirectly addressing an immediate urgency for an ever growing hunger crisis in Nakivale refugee settlement. 

How well are we prepared? Unidos has an answer to that.¬†

As Co-founder of Defiants and sponsor of Unidos you have my recommendation to support unidosprojects¬†

Sincerely,

Gino

LI:
Email

messages.text: "Trees are used to make lump charcoal used as a cooking fuel. The process is smokey and usually far from carbon neutral. messages.text: "The banana or plantain stem is ordinarily a pseudo-stem consisting of an aggregation of leaf stalk bases in cylindrical form. The pseudo-stem is the stem of the banana plant that provides and transports nutrients from the soil to the fruits. It is usually discarded as waste although it could be processed into pulp, fiber, and paper due to its cellulosic content. The height of the banana plant can reach approximately 7.5 m, while the width can reach approximately 30 cm."

text:
Hi Paulinho - I heard back from PINA that the projects they support must be based in North America.  They offered two possiblities that might be helpful:

1) the Permaculture Magazine UK has a contest.  I have been trying to research this and looks liek it is in collaboration witht he Lush Prize and that Unidos Social Innovation Centre won the prize for 2023 - is that your organization?  If so, congratulations! 

2) if it would be helpful to promote awareness of the project, PINA would be happy to set up a live interview with you (as they did with me and Qwiyahwutuhw).  I don't think taht many people attend live, but theyn they are recorded and on PINA's youtube channel and facebook page.  Jesse

mission at all?  If he is interested can you have him fill out this form:

text:
So what I understand is that the last few months you have 

- Explored case studies in other refugee settlements, framing other permaculture initiative that can use funding
- Setup a Food forest pilot in anothe refugee settlement
- Launched a regensoil workshop
- Anything else?

---

Question:

- Did you explore biochar? 
- Can you estimate how much vermicompost you can produce at this stage?
- Have you spoken with farmers that use chemical fertiliser and allow them to try one season with Vermicompost. And if their crop does not provide a high return, cover their loss? 

Aim = To have a clear marketfit for the vermicompost and potential market size in case we could deliver fertiliser to the environment. 

Once we can back this with data from a pilot + interview of this target audience. We have a business model we can present to larger investors. 

---

remember this?
factor to recycle (Regenarative plantane cultivation)

messages.from: Paulinho
messages.text:
Yes, these are small actions I have achieved so far.
We have also planted some nitrogen-fixing trees and crops on our Demonstration site.
About the biochar, I was thinking maybe to find where or people doing this and learn from them and not only limited online as we did with KCCA.
We can produce 1000kg of vermicompost at this stage.

Yes, i did have conversations with some people we trained to try vermicompost but this was not enough for this farming circle until next year.
We only have places where we have been using vermicompost as a demonstration of how crops are growing compared to other places where we didn't use them.
I think this a process that we need to focus on and get results ASAP next year.

Yeah,i will keep on exploring and learn more about these links you shared but I am ensuring you that we are doing our best though the process seems slow
