text.text:
------

The following is what we had send (in case you want to read)

Why does the nominee deserve recognition?

text:
As A young Congolese refugee, Paulinho was faced with a loss of a future, like many more refugees. He arrived with nothing in Nakivale. But was inspired to give everything. Not many believed him, the first 2 years were challenging. 

But determination enabled him to become an educator, a coach, a human rights activist, an environmentalist, and most of all a change maker who understands that the best way to help the displaced is by being displaced. 

 As an avid advocate in "Refugees for Refugees"; he trained more than 1500 people in regenerative agriculture to combat the threat of malnutrition in the largest refugee settlement in the world, Nakivale. 

More than farming alone he is training people, youth and women, to enable them the empowerment to make things happen, in business, in community, in family, and while doing he connects all nations behind one single cause; to end hunger in Nakivale.

text.text: Outline the nominee‚Äôs accomplishments and how they have improved the lives of people forced to flee their homes.

text:
Nakivale is a rather hopeless place, where 44% are unemployed due to a lack of skills, or because of the rigid education system and limited social networks, most, with a majority of women, depend on humanitarian aid.

Also, Uganda's national language is English and most refugees come from non-English speaking countries, breaking the language barrier by teaching refugees English is crucial to ensure economic participation.  

Therefore Paulinho started with founding an organization called Unidos, to train and teach people in business, leadership, and English.  

However, once it became clear that UNHCR was not able to finance refugees a food package of 3$/month, and most could not afford more than 1 meal per day. All while global food prices skyrocketed, dry season prolonged, soil eroded and thus crops kept failing, and a big increase of refugees migrating to Nakivale; he decided to dedicate his efforts to training people in regenerative agriculture. 

Committed to designing human systems that co-evolve in relation to their natural environment, Unidos enabled refugees to shift from dependency on humanitarian aid to start taking care of the soil. 

By using worms they are now able to produce rich fertilizer from the food waste of local markets. And together with planting trees, mitigating and shaping microclimates, they have created an ideal environment to cultivate crops. 

In return, it allowed mutual benefits and a greater expression of a resilient refugee.

Of the more than 1500 refugees Unidos trained in the last 3 years, 60% are growing organic food to sustain their families and 20% are producing and commercializing organic fertilizer to generate income addressing some of their basic needs; clean water, health care, schooling for their children.

Another vital part of community building in Nakivale is the empowerment of women. So far 1000 women were supported; and involved in the planting of 5000 trees (medical and food trees), launched as a campaign to tackle climate change. The leaves of the trees are used in soap making. Until now 700 Litres were produced of which 300 Litres were sold on local markets.

Overall his organization promotes inclusion and hosts communities by co-creating an open learning space to invest, learn, and identify the pressing issues and challenges in the life of many refugees. Paulinho helps them to come up with solutions, taking power in their own hands, instead of being subject to the unpredictable future ahead.

text.text: Give a specific example or story of how the nominee has displayed courage, selflessness, sacrifice, humility and, perhaps, risk in their work on behalf of refugees and others forced to flee their homes.

text: Paulinho and the people he involved (other Congolese refugees), started with Unidos without any governmental (apart from some land that was donated by the Ugandan office of the prime minister) or other NGO support.

More than farming alone he is training people, youth and women, to enable them the empowerment to make things happen, in business, in community, in family, and while doing he connects all nations behind one single cause; to end hunger in Nakivale.
Outline the nominee‚Äôs accomplishments and how they have improved the lives of people forced to flee their homes.

Also, Uganda's national language is English and most refugees come from non-English speaking countries, breaking the language barrier by teaching refugees English is crucial to ensure economic participation.  

Therefore Paulinho started with founding an organization called Unidos, to train and teach people in business, leadership, and English.  

However, once it became clear that UNHCR was not able to finance refugees a food package of 3$/month, and most could not afford more than 1 meal per day. All while global food prices skyrocketed, dry season prolonged, soil eroded and thus crops kept failing, and a big increase of refugees migrating to Nakivale; he decided to dedicate his efforts to training people in regenerative agriculture. 

Committed to designing human systems that co-evolve in relation to their natural environment, Unidos enabled refugees to shift from dependency on humanitarian aid to start taking care of the soil. 

By using worms they are now able to produce rich fertilizer from the food waste of local markets. And together with planting trees, mitigating and shaping microclimates, they have created an ideal environment to cultivate crops. 

In return, it allowed mutual benefits and a greater expression of a resilient refugee.

Of the more than 1500 refugees Unidos trained in the last 3 years, 60% are growing organic food to sustain their families and 20% are producing and commercializing organic fertilizer to generate income addressing some of their basic needs; clean water, health care, schooling for their children.

Another vital part of community building in Nakivale is the empowerment of women. messages.forwarded_from: Gino I we never use DM first
text:
He and his team started by making mud bricks and selling them. With the money, they were able to cover operational costs which enabled them to give lectures and offer free meals to those who participated.

For the first 2 years, they had been encouraging each other without much clarity on what food they and their families would eat. 

This continued until me (Gino) and Paulinho met each other in an online community in October 2021. Paulinho was interested in how blockchain could financially emancipate refugees. 

At the time I was running a marketing agency in the blockchain industry. My dream was always to support a local refugee-led project. And with my background in regenerative agriculture, me and Paulinho discovered a complementary vision.

At the time we met, they had a half-constructed building, destined to become an education center, which they had built with self-made mud bricks on the land donated by the local government. This construction was threatened to crumble by heavy rains during the monsoon season. 

Within a month I was able to gather enough funding to help finalize the construction. And after 3 months I visited the location and I was permitted to enter the refugee settlement, as a teacher in regenerative agriculture. 

This marked a milestone for both Paulinho's
and my own organization

. 

From there I helped him with setting up a strategy for scaling his agriculture initiative, anything related to digital marketing, the administration required to employ teachers, and a monthly fee to cover operational costs and pay for the teachers, donated by my organization. 

Within a year Unidos was flourishing and gained international recognition from NGO's supporting refugee-led initiatives.

In May 2022 Unidos was selected among 8 from the 41 applicants and gained its first fund to scale a vermicomposting unit.

See: 
-

(Title: Camp Composting Project: Nakivale Uganda)

In July 2022 Unidos was selected among 15 from the 1500 applicants, to gain access to the innovation fund, by UNHCR 

See: 
-

In June 2023 Unidos won the Permaculture Magazine Award Organized by Lush Spring Prize 

See: 
-

1) Shift the message from preventing hunger to empowering refugees.
Why? Because people dont trust when you express pity. Show courage, vigour and hope ;)
2) Use a footnote with a clear sentence

, beneath each important announcement/content you make on social media.

Help us grow more love and fund a farmer with 15$.

3) Engage oliver on his recommendations
Links:
Youtube Social Impact
Google for Non-profits
WhyDonate
Globalgiving
4) Become more active and engaging on Linkedin
by telling your story. Make it a daily habbit to spend at least 30 minutes per day on Linkedin.
6) Boost your reach
with these free tools
https://leadconnect.io
or
http://waalaxy.com

Result? instead of getting impressions from 80 users on company page or 200 from his 421 followers

you get 5x that amount
7) Make your funding goals small enough to reach faster success.

This is much easier for people to believe in the project and boost moral whenever small goals are achieved. 

Lower it to 1700$ and market it as: "Kick off 100 farmers for the next season, and help donate for their garden tool kit. With $17 you help a farmer grow organic and delicious food for a whole season!"

messages.from: Paulinho
messages.text:
I am doing well,
It has been a challenging period since the end of 2023 without a doubt.
But what makes us different is the inner resilience that we created in ourselves and this optimism of enduring until things unfold.

What I understood in this entrepreneurial life is when things look desperate, means that you are so close to success.

We are currently busy working on preparing this year , learning from the mistakes we made and figuring out the possibility of improvement while taking notes of different feedback you have been providing .

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
text:
Its indeed a bit confusing but also not correct grammar.

You could ask:

text.text: Do you mean how we sustain the safety of children?

aim to activate (mostly but not only) single mothers and involve them into business training and workshops about female emancipation. We recognise women and thus mothers are the bedrock of our communities, however due to empoverishment they suffer the highest rate of unemployment, and are therefore one of the most vulnerable, which indirectly harms their children. 

As we are very aware women are the most impactful to the wellbeing of their children, we designed our regenerative programs to empower and leverage their lifes. Any safeguard policy for women should impact the life of their children. It does happen we organise activities for children where children also get a free meal. But children are not our key target audience per se.

As for the education center's siting and condition, we ensure that the environment is child friendly.
Proper fencing around playground area, education facilities and residential quarters is provided.
I hope that this answers your question

messages.from: Paulinho
text:
Maybe i dont know how transparency means in term of Funding,
We (team) always make budget of everything we need to achieve during the year and keep track with expenses.
I shared with Dave how much money we received this year and how we use it .
You can also check it here

The reality is that everythings changed especially economically ,
You cant find someone who will accept work for you with a monthly salary of 30$ as we started .
The price is no longer the same for living ,ressources etc.

You may be right to say that it is unclear you dont know where the Funds went but if you reach on ground and see what we acheived ,i am sure you will change your perspective of how you are seeing things.

Here locally ,i am 95% among the Local Organization who are managing well our social media with what are happening on ground.

If you see that we are not transparent enough ,Can you suggest a tool that we can use to me more transparent

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
messages.text:
I think we have an interesting story, with recent achievements should give us an edge and trigger interest with a mentoring incubator to lift this to the next stage.

phase 1:
1) commitment to teach farmers fighting risk of famine, and repairing soils
2) seed investment to support the displaced and supporting regenerative business models, by funding the base; education center construction + digital marketing + business 

phase 2:
3) Successfully closed funding to scale vermicomposting for domestic/community use, and teacher plan
4) won several nominations

---

phase 3:
5) make case study, showcasing the success metrics of pilot of vermicomposting, and potential business model/ projected revenue stream
6) get onboared in incubator to scale towards national reproducer of vermicompost; a regenerative business model that uses its profit to re invest in sustainable development

messages.text:
### Quick summary ###

During this meeting, Gino and Mz discussed the challenges faced in production and the need to optimize it. They also talked about the limitations in food waste collection and explored strategies to expand their reach. Gino suggested creating a PDF presentation and booklet to present the project to potential donors and stakeholders.

### Action items for Gino ###
- [ ] Create a PDF presentation and booklet for the project.
- [ ] Coordinate with Mz to finalize the content and design of the presentation.
- [ ] Print and distribute the booklets to relevant stakeholders.

### Action items for Mz ###
- [ ] Prepare a summary of the project's vision and goals for inclusion in the presentation.
- [ ] Gather information on local laws and regulations regarding waste collection and disposal.
- [ ] Coordinate with Gino to review and finalize the content and design of the presentation.

### Action items for both Gino and Mz ###
- [ ] Discuss and identify potential target areas for expanding food waste collection beyond the refugee settlement.
- [ ] Prepare a list of key points to be included in the booklet for easy reference and communication.
- [ ] Stay in touch and provide updates on progress and any further actions required.

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
text:
Hi Paola,

I am very excited to have discovered your presentation and initiative at ETH Zurich. 

Not sure if you recall me; I have been an active participant in the blockchain space since 2017, and co-founded
a not for profit DeFi community agency focused on social impact, with which we funded

an award winnin refugee led NGO.

Notably, in 2023 founder Paulinho won the Gene Dewey Award after we developed a regeneration model for displaced people with access to farmland

I am looking to scale this particular method, yet for that we also need to scale a consistent funding model. 

In our brief meeting I explained that operational costs do not exceed 400$/month for a team of 10 teachers, I was wondering if you could advice a direction I could take. 

My aim is to transition from Tradfi to Defi funding regenerative economic models for displaced people in a p2p fashion, thus ensuring no middleman/corruption takes a cut.

text_entities.text:
Hi Paola,

I am very excited to have discovered your presentation and initiative at ETH Zurich. 

Not sure if you recall me; I have been an active participant in the blockchain space since 2017, and co-founded
defiants.org
a not for profit DeFi community agency focused on social impact, with which we funded
unidosprojects.org

an award winnin refugee led NGO.

Notably, in 2023 founder Paulinho won the Gene Dewey Award after we developed a regeneration model for displaced people with access to farmland
https://www.unrefugees.org/news/usa-for-unhcr-announces-gene-dewey-refugee-award-winners/

I am looking to scale this particular method, yet for that we also need to scale a consistent funding model. 

In our brief meeting I explained that operational costs do not exceed 400$/month for a team of 10 teachers, I was wondering if you could advice a direction I could take. 

My aim is to transition from Tradfi to Defi funding regenerative economic models for displaced people in a p2p fashion, thus ensuring no middleman/corruption takes a cut.

messages.text:
Resource war and Climate change are pushing nations globally. 

Self sufficiency for large farmer populations and knowing how to retain land in dry and wet seasons is paramount. 

Closing a larger Fund enables to scale in both social and economic directions and within our vision establish a profitable but regenerative fair chain vermicomposting cooperation that can empower Nakivale region. 

I gonna see if I can find lobbyists here in Belgium, for instance the mother of my brother in law is UN commissioner who has been active in Africa. I just never really tried reaching out. Can't promise much, but maybe she knows to point us to the right financer.

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
messages.text:
I recommend using voice over instead of talking in front of camera. This will help to sound more confident. And redo if you made a mistake in your pronouncing and grammar. 

All this talking has to go very smoothly to make a impactful impression.

You are telling a story, and if recording over and over till you speak like a saint (joking ;p)

You catch my drift?

I also recommend to simply start talking with each and record it, this way you can capture pieces 

Lastly, the technical aspect of sound is also very important to leave a certain professional touch in an environment that sustain a nice full sound without distractions of wind, distance, or echo.

We dont need it to be perfect but we want it to be decent and finished.

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
text: This is the plan i introduced to my DeFi client.

In short: 

We will start collecting donations from the revenue stream of Bonzi token in the next coming months. The revenue stream consists of Trading fees people pay to buy or sell bonzi token, and those are collected in a pool. A % of that pool will run into the ReFi Fund. Or Regenerative Finance Fund.

To get more into detail:

We‚Äôre currently developing a new kind of crypto-native funding system, led by a meme mascot named Bonzi. On the surface, it may appear like internet humor or a joke token. But underneath, it‚Äôs designed as a Trojan Horse ‚Äî a viral character that captures the attention of speculative crypto traders while secretly funneling resources into real-world impact. That impact includes you, and the work we‚Äôre doing together for refugee-led development.

The Bonzi system does two things at once:

- It rewards crypto users for holding a token.
- It redirects trading fees into a ReFi fund ‚Äî a regenerative finance pool ‚Äî that we are allocating in part to UnidosProjects.

This new donor is not a foundation or institution in the traditional sense. It‚Äôs a system, fueled by the volume of decentralized trading. The more users engage with the meme, the more the fund grows ‚Äî and the more we can support your work.

In this early phase, we‚Äôre keeping the connection between Bonzi and Unidos hidden from public view. Why? Because people often judge impact-based projects as "charity" ‚Äî and that hurts visibility in the crypto world. Instead, we‚Äôre proving that hidden integrity can be more powerful than performative virtue-signaling.

You are one of the few who know the full story.

text:
I think a good start is you having the ability to own direct access to the receiver cryptowallet. and that defiants, or any new donator can send this money directly to this wallet address. From there we need to find a bridge to fiat, and send fiat to world remit.

I was actually thinking of setting up a multisig wallet with you on gnosis safe, this way multiple people own access, and both need to sign each transaction, improving security and democracy over funds. 

this wallet address we can use to put on our donation page as well, and the multisig wallet will further support our image as non profit organisation.

I explored a potential, route:

text.text: Next steps to help improve finance.

text:
- Setup Multisig wallet with gnosis. And solidify off-ramp bridge to world remit.

- Migrate and Re-design Website Unidos

- Evaluate business model regesoil, setup MOU between founders, explore legal entity model, contact potential partners, lock in 5 year funding, roll-out administrative framework.

- Design website regesoil

Other Notes:

- defiants and Bonzi (new donor) rely on health of financial markets, but can become a potential. 

- regesoil will focus on institutional funding, with new proposed business model 

- mushroom project will continue operate with defiants money as seed fund

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
text: Can you ask him he replaces my bio text with

text.text:
From early on, Gino has immersed himself in fields driven by social and ecological transformation.

Over the past decade, he has contributed to a range of grassroots initiatives, blending creativity and systems-thinking in both design and regenerative practice.

Gino has a background in web and graphic design and spent several years traveling between eco-projects across Southern and Northern Europe. These experiences deepened his interest in permaculture, community living, and sustainable design.

From urban farming to rural land regeneration, Gino‚Äôs journey has been rooted in learning-by-doing‚Äîcollaborating with innovators, land stewards, and local communities to reimagine how we live, grow, and connect.

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
messages.text: Regesoil turns refugee settlement food waste into high-grade vermicompost for EU export, multiplying its value by 10x. We build circular, regenerative agriculture systems while returning 95% of profits directly to refugee communities facing humanitarian shortfalls.

text_entities.text: Regesoil turns refugee settlement food waste into high-grade vermicompost for EU export, multiplying its value by 10x. We build circular, regenerative agriculture systems while returning 95% of profits directly to refugee communities facing humanitarian shortfalls.

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
messages.text:
Regesoil flips the script on economic exclusion for refugee-led NGOs by exporting high-grade African vermicompost to the EU.
We turn 5 tons of local food waste into 1 ton of premium vermicompost ‚Äî valued at ‚Ç¨3,500 in Europe versus ‚Ç¨350 locally.
Nakivale alone generates hundreds of tons of food waste daily, creating massive circular economy potential.
By removing middlemen and returning 95% of profits to refugee communities, we deliver a regenerative agritech solution that builds food security, economic resilience, and climate impact.

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
messages.text:
to reduce cost/ton i removed my own wage, and reduced yours back to 350. and keep staff at 100/month. 

this will also look better in the MOU building a long term cooperative business relationship in line with fairchain/regenerative busines principles. 

only after we have definite market fit we can review again to my own wage for phase 1. But I think a more sustainable goal for me is to wait till we reach phase 2. 

until phase 2 we remain a humanitarian experiment, and not yet a business.

To progress I need to confirm a few things:

1) Can you explain again which infrastructure is still needed to be able to produce 20 ton of vermicompost. 
Or are we fully equipped, and all we need is wages for staff?

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
messages.text:
2) You think it is realistic to produce 20 ton per year with a team of 10 people? And whether we have enough access. With a population of 100k+ people there should be enough, but the question is more how to collect it. And whether alternatives can work such as using manure from Livestock.

The info about our production information should be the most accurate in our business plan. and this will proof we can highly competitive in pricing/ton.

The most ideal way of scaling and benefiting everyone is optimising the production process from manual to automation. This can start mechanically such as sieving with a large tumble with holes in (see image) 

Reasoning we have frame current setup in our business model is to estimate costs to optimise and scale towards 50 ton/year.

This will help to bring the current pilot to life and shows what can be done locally and where we can optimise

messages.from: Gino I we never use DM first
messages.text:
The aim is to understand which input (resources) are you using to get to the output (7ton). Engineering and processing that is taking place.

Lastly I need a clear documentation on what is your nearest source of fodder and when are the harvest moments you can benefit from larger input of worm fodder (foodwaste)

Lastly we also need to understand how the foodwaste is applied, arrre large pieces cut in pieces? Or is no cutting applied at all? 

------

After we mapped this all out we can start to categorise which parts of the process can be improved with larger capacity methods or mechanisms.

messages.from: Paulinho
messages.text:
we proceed the sieving by hand which i will share some short video soon,
THe drying is done in an open air.
Packaging is done by hand as well,
We have so far two facilities with 3 vermicompost unities/
The transportation is limited to one 3 wheeler.
This can carry 700kg per load of waste.

We cut into pieces when we collect so many food waste to enable worms to decompose them rapidely.

messages.forwarded_from: Nakivale Unidos x Defiants Initivative Diary
text:
‚è≥ Only 5 days left!
But together, we can turn 5 days into a lifetime of impact.
Our hearts are full of gratitude to everyone who has supported us so far. As we celebrate 6 years of real impact, we truly mean it. 

This week, we‚Äôll share powerful stories from amazing people we‚Äôve worked with and trained ,people who through courage and persistence found their purpose, gained confidence, and felt empowered socially, economically, culturally, and mentally through our work. ‚ú®

We‚Äôre almost at 30% of our goal, and we still need your support to make this happen. Every contribution brings us closer.
Stay tuned. Stay connected. Be part of the change.

Support our campaign üëâüèΩ

or share this message with your network to help us spread hope even further.
Let‚Äôs welcome more refugees, spread hope, and keep building a community where everyone belongs. ü´Ç

messages.from: Paulinho

text.text:
Paulinho is a dynamic changemaker dedicated to transforming refugee settlements into regenerative communities. In 2018, he received a scholarship from Idea4Africa, where he studied Entrepreneurship, Business, and Leadership, and conducted community-based trainings to help people identify and act on local opportunities. That same year, he founded the Unidos Social Innovation Center, a grassroots organization committed to sustainability, empowerment, and community-led development.

As a certified permaculture teacher through the Permaculture Education Institute and an accredited Warm Data host by the Bateson International Institute, Paulinho brings a systems-thinking approach to community transformation. He is also an Ambassador of the SEEDS regenerative financial ecosystem and a trained Business and Leadership facilitator, promoting horizontal leadership and decentralization through his two years of experience in DAO structures.

Paulinho‚Äôs work in refugee settlements across Uganda focuses on Regenerative Agriculture. Using Permaculture Principles, he co-creates projects that recycle food waste, regenerate soil, and grow nutrient-rich food in ways that heal ecosystems. His initiatives also create jobs, improve food security, and support climate resilience.

His visionary efforts have earned global recognition. He received the Social Impact Award in 2022, the Permaculture Magazine Award in 2023, and was a winner of the Ockenden International Prizes. In 2024, he was honored with the Gene Dewey Refugee Award by the USA for UNHCR, recognizing his exceptional leadership and impact on forcibly displaced communities. Paulinho was also nominated for the prestigious Earthshot Prize.

Additionally, he worked with

as part of the ALTs Team, where he explored how Web3 technologies can unlock job opportunities and decentralized empowerment for refugees.

Paulinho envisions a future where refugee camps are no longer temporary shelters but thriving, regenerative ecosystems with access to clean water, abundant food, and quality education.
